awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Problem Solving Skills as Predictors of Success and Persistence in Biology
awd_abstract_narration:
This CAREER project focuses on understanding problem-solving skills among biology undergraduates. The goals are to: (1) Investigate the problem solving steps of beginning and advanced biology students in the domains of protein structure and function and metabolism; (2) Determine the extent to which the use of particular problem-solving steps by biology students predicts their success and persistence in science; and (3) Apply the findings to enhance problem solving skills.

Longitudinal data are being collected from a cohort of biology undergraduates across their undergraduate careers. Data include students' problem solving steps along with demographic characteristics, academic characteristics, and career intentions. Problem-solving steps are analyzed qualitatively. Hierarchical Generalized Linear Modeling and Hierarchical Linear Modeling are used to determine the extent to which problem-solving skill predicts success and persistence in science. This project expands an online problem solving tutorial to enhance supportive problem solving skills in solving protein structure and function and metabolism problems. Additionally, biology faculty from the university and local high schools are meeting regularly to engage in discussion, implementation, and feedback about how to teach problem solving in biology.

Research in this area is important for greater understanding of how students solve problems which can help educators develop targeted course interventions. Targeted course interventions have been shown to facilitate student success and persistence in science. More widespread success and persistence in science degree programs is necessary to meet the predicted demand for more workers in areas such as health care, biomedical research, and engineering in the United States of America. This project provides insights for building learning and teaching tools to increase the number of undergraduates who are prepared for science career paths. In so doing, the project will contribute to a globally competitive workforce in science in the United States of America. Additionally, the proposed project will increase our understanding of some of the factors that may have impact on the full participation of groups underrepresented in science-related professions.

por.por_cntn:
Many calls from educators and policy makers over the last two decades focus on the need to improve college science instruction. These calls challenge the scientific community to shift college science instruction away from the transmittal of information toward a focus on conceptual understanding and problem solving. In order for college science educators to respond to this call, new knowledge is needed about the ideas students bring to the classroom and how instructors can help students add to, refine, and utilize their ideas for problem solving. This project, referred to as BioSTEPS, generated new knowledge about student thinking in biochemistry.

BioSTEPS focused on two foundational concepts in biochemistry: the physical basis of noncovalent interactions and metabolic pathway dynamics and regulation. The BioSTEPS research team developed a problem-solving assessment to reveal students? ideas about these concepts at three stages of an undergraduate life sciences curriculum. Students responded to the BioSTEPS assessment in writing or in interviews where they more fully explained their problem solving approaches. The team used the findings from students? written and interview responses to design and test new instructional materials.

Key project outcomes include the following:

The research team pinpointed key aspects of student thinking about the physical basis of noncovalent interactions and metabolic pathway dynamics and regulation. The team found that students have many pertinent and accurate ideas about both concepts, yet typically their ideas exist in pieces rather than well-integrated frameworks. For example, when solving problems about noncovalent interactions, students readily recognize the categories of noncovalent interactions, yet they don?t describe the underlying chemical and physical processes that lead to these interactions.

The research team discovered the trajectory of growth in conceptual understanding for both the physical basis of noncovalent interactions and metabolic pathway dynamics and regulation. A cohort of N=145 students completed the BioSTEPS assessment at all three stages: introductory biology, biochemistry, and cell biology. These students showed substantial growth in their conceptual understanding and problem solving from introductory biology to biochemistry and flatter growth from biochemistry to cell biology. The team will continue to explore these data to understand the extent to which growth is influenced by student self-efficacy and intrinsic motivation.  

The research team developed instructional materials that respond to the findings on student thinking. The team showed that these instructional materials lead to improved student learning compared to that among students who did not receive this type of instruction. The team also developed and tested different versions of the instructional materials because it is unknown the extent to which the sequence of problem solving practice and direct instruction matters for maximizing student learning. This work revealed that for problems that closely resemble the ones used during instruction, students can achieve comparable learning whether direct instruction or problem-solving practice comes first. However, this finding still needs to be tested using problems that are more dissimilar from those used during instruction.

The research team also implemented a learning community for high school and college science educators. The learning community met regularly for one year to consider findings from research on student thinking, exchange ideas about teaching, and develop new assessments and lessons that help students deepen their conceptual understanding and apply scientific practices.

The intellectual merit of the BioSTEPS project is in its use of theory and methods that enabled the discovery of novel insights about college biochemistry learning. First, the research team used best practices in educational psychology and discipline-based education research to develop a biochemistry problem-solving assessment that reveals rich information about student thinking. Second, the team utilized a theoretical perspective on student learning known as the pieces perspective that enabled identification of the elemental nature of students? ideas and the way students utilize these ideas across contexts. Third, the research team built collaborations with cognitive scientists who study general mechanisms of learning. These collaborations enabled the team to create different versions of the instructional materials to address open questions about the best way to sequence problem-solving instruction. Fourth, all of these approaches enabled the team to generate new knowledge about biochemistry learning at the college level.

The broader impacts of this project include the following. First, thousands of students participated in the BioSTEPS project by responding to the BioSTEPS assessment and by completing lessons using new instructional materials. Second, more than a dozen high school and college instructors participated in a learning community to better align their teaching with national calls for changes in science instruction. Third, the assessments and instructional materials created as part of this project have been disseminated to provide improved biochemistry instruction. Fourth, this project supported approximately 25 trainees at the undergraduate, graduate, and postdoctoral level, including people from groups historically underrepresented in science. These trainees received ongoing mentorship enabling them to continue contributing to the scientific enterprise in the United States.
